newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: FORMULAB VOLUME ROCKETS AMID EXIT TALK.
newsitem.headline: FORMULAB VOLUME ROCKETS AMID EXIT TALK.

text.p: Shares in computer technology developer Formulab Neuronetics Corp Ltd rocketed to the top of the turnover list on Wednesday with a total of 179.38 million shares traded amid talk founder Tony Richter had exited the company.
The bulk of the business was in two lines of 150.54 million and 28.25 million, both at 25 cents per share, specialled through Prudential-Bache Securities Australia.
Brokers said market speculation was that Richter had sold out, with the shares going to a group of U.S. institutional investors.
The large volumes were accounted for by the release from escrow of shares held by Richter, the brokers said.
Formulab was not available for comment.

The company was formed to launch the Richter Paradigm Computer, a computer system that is supposed to mimic the human brain and that can process more complex problems than existing personal computers.
On July 11, Formulab appointed former Insignia Solutions Plc chief executive Robert P. Lee as chief executive officer of both Formulab and its wholly owned U.S. subsidiary, Richter Paradigm Corp.
Richter remained as executive chairman of Formulab and chairman of the technical committee.

On July 11 Richter Paradigm Corp signed an alliance with Tandem Computers Incorporated to pursue activities to promote the use of each other's products, while on August 5 the company said it had met all the requirements for Microsoft Corp licencing on Windows 95 and Window NT.
Formulab shares closed three cents higher at 28.5 cents.
However, by 6.00 p.m. (0800 GMT), the two special lines had been cancelled by the Australian Stock Exchange (ASX) through its Stock Exchange Automated Trading System (SEATS).
No ASX official was available to explain the cancellation.
